output.conclusion: This course provides a solid foundation in inorganic chemistry, equipping students with the knowledge and skills necessary for further study in related fields.
output.introduction: Welcome to Intermediate Inorganic Chemistry! This course builds upon your existing knowledge of chemistry to explore the fascinating world of inorganic compounds, their structures, properties, and reactions.

chapters.description: Review of atomic structure, electronic configurations, and the periodic table. Focus on trends in ionization energy, electronegativity, atomic size, and electron affinity.
Exploration of ionic, covalent, and metallic bonding. Introduction to molecular orbital theory and its application to simple inorganic molecules.

modules.moduleTitle: Fundamentals of Atomic Structure and Bonding

chapters.description: Definition of coordination complexes, ligands, and metal ions. Nomenclature and isomerism in coordination compounds.
Valence bond theory and crystal field theory applied to coordination complexes. Factors affecting crystal field splitting.
Lewis acid-base theory, hard and soft acids and bases (HSAB principle), and acid-base reactions in non-aqueous solvents.
Balancing redox reactions, electrochemical series, and applications of redox reactions in inorganic chemistry.

chapters.chapterTitle: Descriptive Chemistry of Main Group Elements (Part 1)
chapters.description: Detailed study of the properties, reactions, and applications of Group 1 and Group 2 elements (alkali and alkaline earth metals).

chapters.chapterTitle: Descriptive Chemistry of Main Group Elements (Part 2)
chapters.description: Detailed study of the properties, reactions, and applications of Group 13-18 elements (focus on trends and unique properties).
General properties of transition metals, oxidation states, and common coordination geometries.
Introduction to organometallic compounds, ligands, and bonding interactions between metals and organic ligands.
